title: 'Creepy' giant photos of residents that were placed above train station are removed
text:
Giant billboards featuring the faces of locals above a train station have been removed following years of complaints by community.

The artwork was established in 2006 above the Cockburn train station in Western Australia.

The billboards feature the digitally morphed faces on hundreds of local residents.

Giant billboards featuring the faces of locals above a train station have been removed following years of complaints by community

The billboards feature the digitally morphed faces on hundreds of local residents

Despite calls to have the artwork removed it was sun damage and cracking that was the eventual reason they were pulled down.

The transport authority carried out the work in the middle of the night this week.

'Apparently there was a bit that looked like it was going to fall down,' Transport Minister Rita Saffioti told 9 News.

Ms Saffioti explained it was not decided what would replace the artwork yet but that locals would have a say.

She said a survey would soon be sent out to the community asking what they preferred to see at the site.

'It was weird and creepy,' one local told the broadcaster.

'I've been here for about ten years and I think it's about time to get something new,' agreed another.

Cockburn city councillor Lara Kirkwood was behind a petition to have the artwork pulled down.

Ms Kirkwood said her constituents always complained about the artwork and looked forward to seeing something else established that would better represent the city.

Cockburn city councillor Lara Kirkwood was behind a petition to have the artwork pulled down
description: The artwork was established in 2006 above the Cockburn train station in Western Australia. The billboards feature the digitally morphed faces on hundreds of locals.
authors: Brett Lackey For Daily Mail Australia
